Collective bargaining/the right to #strike when negotiations¬†fail is a proud American tradition - I proudly stand with organized #Labor and the @UAW as a counterbalance to corporate power and as they wield their influence to effectuate  change for their workplace and @GM workers.
Together, we can root out the corruption in Washington. We can make big, structural changes that will restore our trust in government. And when I‚Äôm President, that‚Äôs exactly what I plan to do.

That‚Äôs not all. I've also released plans to make sure that no president is above the law, to tackle defense contractor coziness at the Pentagon, and to expand oversight, transparency, and enforcement for all contractors hired by the federal government.

We'll fix our criminal laws to make sure we can hold corrupt officials accountable. And we'll ensure that our federal agencies and courts work for the people. That includes holding our federal judiciary‚Äîincluding the Supreme Court‚Äîto the highest ethical standards.

We'll end lobbying as we know it, strengthening our lobbying laws and helping to break the grip that lobbyists have on our government. The voices of corporations and powerful interests shouldn‚Äôt be the only voices influencing government‚Äîbut that‚Äôs exactly what‚Äôs happened.

We'll start by strengthening public integrity rules for federal officials in every branch of government, rooting out financial conflicts of interest, and slamming shut the revolving door between government and industry.

My plan lays out the most sweeping set of anti-corruption reforms since Watergate‚Äînearly one hundred proposals. The goal is simple: Take power away from the wealthy and the well-connected and put it back where it belongs‚Äîin the hands of the people.

But these problems didn‚Äôt start with Trump. On issue after issue, widely popular policies are blocked because corporations and billionaires use their money and influence to stop any progress. To fix it, we‚Äôll need big, structural change to fundamentally transform our government.

The Trump administration is the most corrupt of our lifetimes. Trump is a walking conflict of interest, and many of his cabinet secretaries are no better. His Supreme Court Justices were hand-picked by right-wing extremist groups, and some of his donors are now ambassadors.

In 2019, just 17% of Americans trusted government to do the right thing. Why? Because our government works great for the wealthy and well-connected, but not for everyone else. That‚Äôs corruption, plain and simple‚Äîand I‚Äôve got a plan to fight back. http://elizabethwarren.com/plans/end-washington-corruption

Like a schoolyard bully, Iran will only respond when you stand up to them. 

They won‚Äôt stop until forced to do so.

When Iran shot down a U.S. drone in June, we should have responded directly. 

In this case, Iran is attacking Saudi Arabia, our ally ‚Äî so we should support a Saudi response.

If the latest drone attacks in Saudi Arabia originated from Yemen, this is exactly what the Saudis and other Gulf states feared: an Iranian-backed militia on their wide open southern border. Another Hezbollah.
If we stop economic sanctions against Iran, they will kick their nuclear development program into overdrive. This is dangerous for the Middle East and the globe.

Iran's ultimate goal is to get the U.S. to de-escalate and ease sanctions. They're acting out to change the narrative that peace can only be achieved if we stop exerting economic pressure.

If intelligence proves Iranian responsibility for these recent attacks on Saudi Arabia, we should weigh our options carefully and consult with our regional and European allies and partners, which will only strengthen our response.

Still, Iran is the world‚Äôs top state sponsor of terrorism and continues to destabilize the Middle East in places like Yemen, Syria, Lebanon, and Iraq. U.S. military power helps to deter Iran from taking additional military action through its proxies.

The U.S. and Saudi Arabia have had an important partnership for decades, but Saudi Arabia is not a treaty ally, and the killing of Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi and the conduct of the Saudi-led coalition in Yemen have strained our relationship.
Under our Constitution, the President cannot wage war unless there is an imminent threat to the United States or Americans abroad. Military force should be the last resort.
